I know nobody can do me no harm

Throughout this song Lennon is likening his romantic partner and the pleasure he derives from her to a ‘loaded gun’. This line reinforces the safety and comfort level that he has when he is with Yoko Ono, similar to the safety that one may feel with a loaded gun. He knows that no one can take away this feeling of euphoria he ha when he is with her.
...down

Lennon had originally sang the “I need a fix” verse twice, but when creating the stereo mix, George Martin had faded out the first occurrence to give prominence to George Harrison’s solo. However, before the verse ended Martin inadvertantly faded the vocal part back up and the last word “down” can be heard in the official version.
I need a fix ’cause I’m going down

It expresses the drug addiction that John Lennon had at the moment of writing “The White Album” and even before. That is, he used drugs to stimulate his creative thinking and overcome his problems (like his divorce with Cynthia Powell)

Lying with his eyes while his hands are busy
 Working overtime

According to The Beatles Bible, this line is based around a story Apple’s publicist, Derek Taylor, had heard in the news and mentioned to John Lennon.

The hands busy working overtime […] referred to a story heard by Taylor about a man who used false hands as an elaborate shoplifting technique.
And I feel my finger on your trigger

John’s describing sex with Mother Superior, Yoko Ono. It makes it twice as alluring because she’s described as a religious figure- a forbidden pleasure. It’s unusual as well that Lennon called Ono Mother at times. Oedipal? Yes.

She gives him the same security as a gun would.
The song’s sexually suggestive lyrics were picked up upon by BBC, and “Happiness is a Warm Gun” was banned in the United Kingdom.
[Chorus]
This section is in doo-wop. Doo-wop features vocal group harmony, nonsense syllables, a simple beat, sometimes little or no instrumentation, and simple music and lyrics.
Like a lizard on a window pane

The lizard on the window pane was a recollection from Derek Taylor’s days living in Los Angeles.

The first section of the song was made up of phrases thought up by Lennon and Apple’s publicist Derek Taylor during an acid trip the pair experienced along with Neil Aspinall and Lennon’s childhood friend Pete Shotton.
She’s well-acquainted with the touch of the velvet hand

Alludes to a fetishist who told Apple press officer Derek Taylor and Lennon that wearing moleskin gloves gave him “a little bit of an unusual sensation when I’m out with my girlfriend.”

Lennon and Derek Taylor were on an acid trip at the time. The LSD experience was described by Alan Watts as: “revelations of the secret workings of the brain, of the associative and patterning processes, the ordering systems which carry out all our sensing and thinking”.
Hence, the stream of conscious imagery in this tune.

A soap impression of his wife which he ate
 And donated to the National Trust

This refers to people defecating on public land – a common problem John Lennon encountered walking around Liverpool.

According to Derek Taylor in A Hard Day’s Write this image

came from a conversation we’d had about the horrors of walking in public spaces on Merseyside, where you were always coming across the evidence of people having crapped behind bushes and in old air raid shelters. So to donate what you’ve eaten to the National Trust was what would now be known as ‘defecation on common land owned by the National Trust.’
Happiness is a warm gun

The “warm gun” is a metaphor for Lennon’s sexual desires for Yoko Ono, but many people also interpret these lines to be about shooting heroin (which Lennon denied in later interviews).

John Lennon got the song title of the song from the cover of a gun magazine.



“Happiness is a warm gun” is a wordplay, based off the title of the 1962 “Peanuts” book, “Happiness Is A Warm Puppy”



A warm gun also represents a gun that has just been fired.
